questiontext.text:
Combining Wave Equations

Key Point

If  \(A\cos\theta+B\sin\theta= C\cos (\theta-\alpha)\)  then  \(C=\sqrt{A^2+B^2}\) and \( \tan\alpha=\dfrac{B}{A}.\)

Note that the following cases arise for the location of \(\alpha\):

 \[ \quad 1.\quad  A>0,  B>0 : \text{ 1st  quadrant } \] \[ \quad 2.\quad  A<0,  B>0 :\text{ 2nd quadrant } \] \[ \quad 3.\quad A<0, B<0 : \text{ 3rd quadrant } \] \[ \quad 4.\quad A>0, B<0 : \text{ 4th quadrant } \]


In terms of waves, using Key Point above we have\[ \quad R_1\cos\omega t+R_2\sin\omega t= R\cos (\omega t-\alpha)\]  where \(R=\sqrt{R^2_1+R^2_2} \)  and \(  \tan \alpha=\dfrac{R_2}{R_1}\).

The form \(R\cos (\omega t-\alpha)\) is said to be the  amplitude/phase form of the wave.

Example

Express in the form \(C\cos (\theta-\alpha)\) each of the following:

   

  1.  \(3\cos\theta+3\sin\theta\)

  2. \(-3\cos\theta+3\sin\theta\)

  3. \(-3\cos\theta-3\sin\theta\)

  4. \(3\cos\theta-3\sin\theta\)

Solution

   

  1.  \(\tan\alpha=\dfrac{B}{A}=\dfrac{3}{3}=1\) gives \(\alpha=45^\circ\)   (\(A\) and \(B\) are both positive so the first quadrant is the correct one.) Hence \( 3\cos\theta+3\sin\theta=\sqrt{18}\cos(\theta-45^\circ)= \sqrt{18}\cos\left(\theta-\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right)\)

  2. The angle \(\alpha\) must be in the second quadrant as \(A=-3<0\), \(B=+3>0\). By calculator : \(\tan\alpha=-1\) gives \(\alpha=-45^\circ\) but this is in the 4th quadrant. Remembering that \(\tan\alpha\) has period \(\pi\) or \(180^\circ\) we must therefore add \(180^\circ\) to the calculator value to obtain the correct \(\alpha\) value of \(135^\circ\). Hence \[ \quad \qquad -3\cos\theta+3\sin\theta=\sqrt{18}\cos(\theta-135^\circ)\]

  3. Here \(A=-3,\ B=-3\) so \(\alpha\) must be in the 3rd quadrant. \(\tan \alpha=\dfrac{-3}{-3}=1\) giving \(\alpha=45^\circ\) by calculator. Hence adding \(180^\circ\) to this tells us that \[ \quad -3\cos\theta-3\sin\theta=\sqrt{18}\cos(\theta-225^\circ)\]

  4. Here \(A=3,\ B=-3\) so \(\alpha\) is in the 4th quadrant. \(\tan\alpha=-1\) gives us (correctly) \(\alpha=-45^\circ\) so \[ \quad \qquad 3\cos\theta-3\sin\theta=\sqrt{18}\cos(\theta+45^\circ).\] Note that in the amplitude/phase form the angle may be expressed in degrees or radians.
